Tech News

DNC Serves WikiLeaks With Lawsuit Via Twitter

In an unusual move, the US District Court for the Southern District of New York granted a motion by the Democratic National Committee (DNC) to serve WikiLeaks by way of a tweet. The firm representing the DNC had asked the court for permission to use Twitter to serve the defendant after more traditional methods of service had failed. Service by Twitter is not unprecedented. In granting the DNC’s motion, the court cited a 2016 case in which the court authorized service by tweet.

FCC Says Court Made Error in Approval of AT&T/Time Warner Merger

The US Department of Justice (DOJ) has appealed the decision of a federal district court allowing the merger of AT&T and Time Warner Cable. The FCC, which did not join the DOJ in opposing the merger, has submitted a filing in the appeal that argues the district court erred in not giving enough weight to some of the evidence presented.

Ajit Pai Loses In Court--FCC Can’t Kill Broadband Subsidy in Tribal Areas

The US Court of Appeals for the DC Circuit has stayed an order by the FCC to limit eligibility for the Tribal Lifeline enhanced subsidy to “facilities-based” service providers in rural areas. This subsidy reduces the cost of internet and phone service for low-income residents of federal Tribal reservations. According to the ruling, the plaintiff tribes showed a substantial risk that tribal populations would “suffer widespread loss of vital telecommunications services absent a stay,” and the FCC did not carry its burden of proving that its plan would not result in “mass disconnection.”

Google Employees Protest Secret Work on Censored Search Engine for China

The New York Times reports that it obtained a letter signed by over a thousand Google employees who are upset at the search giant’s decision to secretly build a censored version of its search engine in China. The Times points out that Google employees have previously been outspoken about the company’s decisions and policies, such as its involvement in a weapons program by the US government, and have effectively advocated for changes.

ISPs Say They Can’t Expand Broadband Unless Government Gives Them More Money

Although internet service providers (ISPs) have long battled being classified as utilities (and thus being subject to more stringent regulations than they currently are), Ars Technica reports that they are now asking for the government for the same type of assistance provided to utility companies, under the rationale that they are, essentially, utilities as well.

Google Updates Location History Language After Tracking Backlash

In mid-August, Google admitted that it continues to track users even after users disable location history tracking. Four days after this admission, Google updated its website to more accurately reflect the nature of its location policy. The Google Account Help page now states that disabling location history tracking does not affect Google Location Services and Find My Device, and that “[s]ome location data may be saved as part of your activity on other services, like Search and Maps.”

Google Releases a Searchable Database of US Political Ads

Google recently released a database of all US political ads that have run on its platform. The database, dubbed Ad Library, is fully searchable and browsable and can be filtered and sorted across a number of different parameters, including candidate name or advertiser, spend, the dates the ads were live, impressions, and type of ad.

SEO News

20 Call-To-Action Phrases That Will Boost Conversion Rates Fast

Strong, targeted calls to action are a proven way to increase conversion rates, according to a recent HubSpot study. Hubspot conducted its study on 93,000 marketing campaigns that employed call-to-action phrases. The study’s findings indicate that these targeted phrases led to a significant improvement in conversions in comparison with campaigns that employed more generic action phrases. Here are twenty phrases that include words deemed effective in call-to-action marketing campaigns.

Google Adds More Classic Features to the New Search Console

The newest version of Google’s Search Console includes three legacy features that were once solely available in its classic version of Search Console. Users and permissions can now be managed, in addition to the ability to add sites and validate ownership. A Mobile Usability report may also be accessed. Although it is technically available to everyone, Google’s new Search Console remains in beta largely in part because it lacks the full set of the features available in the classic version. This may change, moving Search Console out of beta, as Google continues to add legacy features going forward.

Facebook Challenges Google in Local Search

Long considered the frontrunner of Local Search, Facebook is beginning to challenge Google with its latest mobile app update. Local businesses can now benefit from changes that make it simpler for prospective customers to locate and interact with them as Facebook’s app continues to transform into a helpful tool in its users’ daily lives. Facebook has also redesigned its mobile pages for easier interaction between businesses and their customers. Users can now also tap on action buttons to book appointments, order products and services, and write Recommendations.

Google Posts Added to Local Packs For Some Branded Queries

Traditionally, Google chose to show Google Posts in instances where a single local panel appeared for a particular business. More recently, Google now seems to be showing Google Posts in web search in the local three-pack, specifically on mobile searches. If, for example, an individual searches for certain branded queries on their mobile device, Google may now show a “Posts” tab that reflects that brand’s Google Posts.

Google Extends Extra Characters of Responsive Search Ads to Text Ads

Google will soon begin rolling out responsive search ads to more accounts in select languages. Starting at the end of August, advertisers were allowed to add a third headline to their existing text ads, plus a second description of up to 90 characters. Back in July, Google announced its intention to roll out its new ad format globally in the coming months. Continuing the trend of longer and bigger text ads, this extra character benefit will become available to new responsive text ads in English, French, German, and Spanish beginning in September.

Social Media News

Facebook Now Requiring Pages With Large US Audiences to Go Through Additional Authorization

Facebook Pages that boast large US followings will now be more difficult for people to undermine via fake or compromised accounts. Facebook has recently implemented a “Page Publishing Authorization” process that requires Page managers to verify their location and secure their accounts. Facebook says that the process only takes a couple of minutes to complete. A Page that requires such authorization will reflect a notification on top of its News Feed, which then directs its admins to begin the process.

Twitter Suspends Alex Jones and Infowars for Seven Days

In mid-August, Twitter suspended accounts of far-right Alex Jones and his media website, Infowars. The dual action prevented Jones and InfoWars from tweeting or retweeting content from their respective Twitter accounts for seven days, although it had no affect on their ability to browse the social network. The suspension resulted after both accounts posted a video, which called for their supporters to ready their rifles against media and other individuals they viewed as opponents. This was deemed a violation of Twitter’s rules against inciting violence.

Justice Department Argues Trump Could Block Anyone He Wants on Twitter, Not Obliged to Let People 'Piggyback' on His Tweets

The US Department of Justice is appealing a May 2018 ruling that President Trump violated the constitution by blocking users from his Twitter account. The administration argued that Trump uses the account in his personal capacity, meaning that he should not be obligated to engage with members of the public via the social media platform. The White House previously stated that Trump’s tweets were official statements, but did not specify whether this was in reference to Trump’s personal account or the president’s official account.

Reddit Says It Was Hacked in June and Attackers Got Private Messages and Other Info of Early Users

Reddit has announced that hackers gained access to one of its databases in June 2018, and obtained email addresses, private messages, and other personal data belonging to people who used the site between 2005 and 2007. The breach doesn’t involve users who have only accessed the site since 2007. Reddit is requiring password changes for the affected users, and encouraging password changes for all others.

Twitter Lite Expands To 21 More Countries, Adds Push Notifications

The data-saving version of Twitter, Twitter Lite, has been released to 21 additional countries, making it available in 45 countries overall. Twitter Lite was released in the Philippines last fall, and has since been rolled out to other countries where low bandwidth could otherwise be a barrier to using the app. Twitter’s objective in expanding Twitter Lite has been to grow its user base, which has been relatively stagnant.

Twitter Kills Off Third-Party App Features

After warning developers for many years, Twitter has finally restricted third-party apps from access to its APIs. Users of these apps will lose certain features, including push notifications and automated refreshes to their timelines. Twitter is implementing this restriction in order to dedicate more resources to its native app.

Legal Industry News

ABA Model Rules on Lawyer Advertising to Be Modernized

In a culmination of two years of work by the ABA Standing Committee on Ethics and Professional Responsibility, the ABA House of Delegates has approved changes to the Model Rules of Professional Conduct related to attorney advertising. Though the revisions were not necessarily large scale, they served to streamline and modernize certain rules. Notable changes include that attorneys can now list websites and email addresses instead of office addresses as their contact information in marketing materials, lawyers can refer to themselves as “specialists” based on their experience if it is not misleading to do so, and they may also give small “thank you” gifts to referral sources. The Model Rules are not binding on attorneys, but most states have adopted them in some form in their codes of professional conduct for lawyers.

With Little Fanfare, Trump and McConnell Reshape the Nation’s Circuit Courts

While the nomination of Brett Kavanaugh to the US Supreme Court has garnered most of the media’s attention, President Trump and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell have continued to reshape the judiciary out of the spotlight by filling vacancies on the federal appellate bench with conservative jurists. With the Supreme Court taking relatively fewer cases than in years past, federal appellate court rulings often become the law of the land in their individual circuits. However, a change in control of Congress this November could stall the progress that conservatives have made on this front.

ABA Works to Meet Immigrants’ Increased Need For Legal Assistance and Oppose Family Separations

ABA President Hilarie Bass traveled to South Texas in June to observe the effects of the Trump administration’s “zero tolerance” policy on migrant families who have been separated as a result of it, and to assess how attorneys can help. There she met with staff from the ABA’s South Texas Pro Bono Asylum Representation Project (“ProBAR”), which matches volunteer attorneys with asylum seekers. ProBAR staff and other advocates have seen increased difficulties under the Trump administration for those seeking asylum, who are often denied access to legal ports of entry, and arrested after crossing the border elsewhere. Pro bono organizations have received an overwhelming response from attorneys looking to volunteer their services to help separated families receive due process and ultimately be reunited.

Recent cases involving expert witness testimony:


Economics Expert Not Allowed to Testify on Disability Claims

Plaintiff's Economic Expert Witness was not allowed to testify on disability claims since the expert did not have any medical training.


Circuit Court Denies Admiralty & Maritime Expert Witness from Testifying

Defendant's Admiralty & Maritime Expert Witness did not show that his experimental tests were substantially similar to how plaintiff used his boat.


Finance Expert Witness Allowed to Testify Securities Fraud Case

The court found Finance Expert Witness's "Event Study" provides an evidentiary basis for causation and damages in securities fraud case.
